body.p:
I have just read in the last Asmoneon
(handed me by a friend) Mr A Breslaws attack upon
you; I pray you not to notice or advert to it in
any manner, the letter bears the evidence and impress
of a man of a low bred and loose character—it is in
truth a “scurrilous thing”

Pericles is made to utter the following sentences
and I give them to you in the language of his historian Thucidides
body.quote:
“ To be censured and maligned for a time hath been the
fate of all those whose merit hath raised them above the common
level, but wise and judicious is the man who enjoying the
superiority, dispiseth the envy.”
body.p:
This man M H Breslaw, would like no better
opportunity than to be made famous at your expensce.
Trust him, Mr Lyon, and his sattellites with the supreme
contempt they deserved= I enclose transcribe for you a public notice which
I remember to have read some time ago. I have just looked for and
found it. London Jewish Chronicle, July 14-21-28 Aug 4.
11-25th. “public notice.” It is most particularly requested
that no money be paid to Mr M H Bresslaw, on account
of the Jewish Chronicle, he having long ceased to be in the
employment of the proprietor, Joseph Mitchelo”
This must mean something—therefore a man

who has been publicly advertized for more than two months consecutively for some “delinquency” as the
must suppose—is no fit person for Isaac Leeser to
contend or enter into a controversy with under no circumstances
whatever. I wrote you when you invited the anonymous
correspondent to come forward and when your article appeared
on the subject that I thought it impolitic, I feared the
result—and my fear, has been realized.

Now my good friend=all this comes form contending
about Trifles—and the note I sent you to be affixed
to my article comes in admirably—What do the public
or the readers of the Occident care, about who gives a Get
or How it is given,—whether Mr Nuerbaum marries
on Honer—or on Kipur Day.—let all such things
stand on their own merits, and for the future take
an enlarged view of these Trifles and allow, Mr Levin
Abrahams and his set to become Trifles if they will,
do you not see that there is no Religion in it

You have translated and given us “Jerusalem” Why
not advocate Mendelsons views,—Thise is a Harbor to be reached
The good ship has been tossed about on the seas of Biscbay & superstition for
over one Hundred years on American Seas and no land in sight yet.
It is is it not time to consult the charts given us
by Moses & the Prophets and by whether, we may not
be able to reach the much desired Haven of Religion
look at the numberless young men. (the best sailors) that
have deserted the ship by escaping over the side, ? (intermanagers)
preferring to swim to some shore rather than remain on board
where there is so much contention and strife about things
of no consequence that they became disgusted—is it not

imperatively demanded that we should let our children
know that there is a true course to be steered and
that, our religion is not one of Contention but of peace
and good will to all men,

It is all nonsense to expect to govern men by a code
of Laws which their own actions plainly speak that they do
not recognized the authority of the men who made them and will not
be governed except by & with their own consent.—

and. yet. these people who neither practice Biblical Laws & orders? or make a great noise when attacked
guided by circumstances hazards an opinion on a Rabbinic affair which conflicts
with the opinion of another, perhaps less qualified to Judge
on the case, you begin to feel what it is to be crushed
and h?ed down without mercy for a Trifle,—therefore
let them ? alone for the future. And continue your exe?
for the moral and religious improvement of the people
make them feel and understand know that they stand under a
Law that they cannot exert without Religion—when this is
achieved and the restire? horses are broken in to harness harness—
you can lead them or drive them on any road
and to any place you like.

I have written this not out of abundance of
leisure time, but of true affection towards you.
Simon aged about 17 or 18 died last night}
he has been in ill health for years.—
